Title:
A revised subtribal classification of Gnaphalieae
(Asteraceae)
Abstract:
The Gnaphalieae are one of the larger tribes of the daisy
family Asteraceae and range globally across a wide range of habitats.
Recent years have seen considerable advances in our understanding of
their phylogenetics and evolution, but there is no widely accepted,
stable subtribal classification. The present paper summarises the
taxonomic history and the various clades that have been named informally
in phylogenetic studies. Based on published studies, our own
comprehensive phylogenetic analyses, and consensus among a number of
Gnaphalieae taxonomists we suggest a subdivision of the tribe into two
subtribes. These are a largely African endemic Relhaniinae and a vastly
enlarged Gnaphaliinae, the latter accounting for more than 90% of the
species diversity. Although a finer division may be desirable, there are
at present several obstacles to such a classification, in particular
contradictory or ambiguous inferences of relationships within the
Gnaphaliinae and the nested position of its largest putative
clades.
